children.name: order
children.definition: /ˈɔːʳdəʳ/  a situation in which everything is controlled, well organized, and correctly arranged :
examples: trật tự
▪ can we have a bit of order here? someone straighten those desks out to start with!
chúng ta có chút trật tự ở đây được không? ai đó kê thẳng bàn để bắt đầu.
impose ordergive something order
▪ he developed a filing system to try to impose order on the mass of information.
anh ta phát triển hệ thống hồ sơ để thiết lập trật tự cho khối thông tin khổng lồ.

children.name: order b2
children.definition: ordernountidy
examples: [ u ] when everything is arranged in its correct place
_the house was so untidy that she spent the whole day trying to establish some sort of order.

children.name: format c1
children.definition: formatnoun
examples: a pattern, plan or arrangement
_the meeting will have the usual format - introductory session, group work and then a time for reporting back.

children.name: organized c1
children.definition: organized,uk usuallyorganisedadjectiveusing system
examples: arranged according to a particular system
the letters had been placed in organized piles, one for each letter of the alphabet.

children.name: rank c1
children.definition: rankverb
examples: to have a position higher or lower than others, or to be considered to have such a position
_a captain ranks (= has a position)abovea lieutenant.
_my entry was ranked third in the flower show.
_she ranked the bottlesin order ofsize along the shelf.
_in my opinion, he ranksamongthe theatre's greatest actors.
_she said that 1989 must rankas(= be) the most remarkable year for change ineuropesince 1848.

children.name: come under sth c1
children.definition: come understhphrasal verbin a book
examples: if a piece of information comes under a particular part of a list, book, or collection
of things, you can find it in that part
_swimming pools usually come under 'leisure centres' in the telephone directory.

children.name: classification c2
children.definition: classificationnoun
examples: [ u ] the act or process of dividing things into groups according to their type
_do you understand the system of classification used in ornithology?

children.name: reconstruct c2
children.definition: reconstructverb
examples: if you reconstruct something that has happened in the past, you combine a lot ofinformation in
order to get a complete description of what happened
_the police tried to reconstruct the crime using the statements of witnesses.

children.name: to arrange sth in a particular way
organize b2
children.definition: organizealsoorganisebritish /ˈɔːʳgənaɪz/  to arrange something so that it is clear, effective, or tidy: tổ chức
examples: ▪ i like the way you’ve organized the information in the report.
▪ you need to organize your financial records and figure out exactly how much money you owe.
organize something into groups/piles/sections etc
▪ the paintings in the exhibition are organized into five sections.
organizationalsoorganisationbritish /ˌɔːʳgənaɪˈzeɪʃənǁ-gənə-/ [uncountable noun] the way something is organized:
▪ getting the project finished on time required careful organization and a lot of teamwork.

children.name: sort out x
children.definition: sort out to organize a group of things that is mixed up or untidy, or organize a lot of information that is confusing or unclear: sắp xếp, phân loại,chọn ra
examples: ▪ after class we needed time to sort out the enormous amount of information we had been given.
▪ first let’s sort out all the pieces before we try putting them together.
▪ when are you going to sort all these files out?

children.name: structure c2
children.definition: structure/ˈstrʌktʃəʳ/  to carefully organize a piece of writing or a system so that it is easy to understand or use:
examples: kết cấu, tổ chức
▪ i have structured the book so that the main points are revisited several times.
tôi đã kết cấu cuốn sách để có thể xem lại những điểm chính nhiều lần.
▪ if we structure the meeting effectively, i think we should be able to cover everything.
nếu chúng ta tổ chức buổi họp hiệu quả thì mọi chuyện đã xong rồi.
structure[uncountable noun] cấu trúc
▪ the structure of the u.s. education system lacks centralization.

children.name: system b1
children.definition: system/ˈsɪstɪm, ˈsɪstəm/  the way that something is organized, following fixed rules and methods, in order to provide a service or achieve an aim:
examples: hệ thống
▪ we’re going to have to make some changes - this system just doesn’t work.
chúng ta sẽ phải thực hiện một số thay đổi - hệ thống này không hoạt động.
▪ most teachers are opposed to recent changes in the education system.
hầu hết giáo viên đều phản đối những thay đổi gần đây trong hệ thống giáo dục.
system of
hệ thống của
▪ what we need is a cheap and reliable system of public transportation.
những gì chúng ta cần là một hệ thống giao thông công cộng rẻ và đáng tin cậy.
▪ a democratic system of government
một hệ thống dân chủ của chính phủ
system for (doing) something
hệ thống cho (làm) gì đó
▪ they are introducing a system for dealing with enquiries from customers.
họ đang giới thiệu một hệ thống để giải quyết yêu cầu của khách hàng.

children.name: set-up x
children.definition: set-up/ˈset ʌp/ informalthe way in which things are organized or done within a company, school etc:
examples: cơ cấu, thiết lập
▪ my last school was quite traditional, but it’s a different set-up at the new one.
trường học cuối cùng của tôi là khá truyền thống, nhưng đó là một sự cơ cấu khác biệt ở trường mới.
▪ an efficient accounts set-up can not only save a company money: it can improve its relationship with its clients.
thiết lập tài khoản hiệu quả có thể không chỉ tiết kiệm được tiền của công ty: nó có thể cải thiện mối quan hệ với khách hàng.

children.name: network b2
children.definition: network/ˈnetwɜːʳk/  a system oflines, tubes, wires, roads etcthat are connected to each other:
examples: mạng lưới, hệ thống
▪ a 24-hour strike brought the railway network to a standstill.
cuộc đình công kéo dài 24 giờ đã làm cho mạng lưới đường sắt bế tắc.
▪ us companies have invested heavily in their telecommunications networks.
các công ty hoa kỳ đã đầu tư rất nhiều vào mạng viễn thông của họ.
network of
mạng lưới của
▪ a network of veins and arteries carries the blood around the body.
một mạng lưới tĩnh mạch và động mạch mang máu xung quanh cơ thể.

children.name: framework c2
children.definition: framework/ˈfreɪmwɜːʳk/  a basic system of rules or ideas that people work within:
examples: khuôn khổ, khung
▪ how do you feel you can develop your skills within the framework of the team?
làm thế nào để bạn cảm thấy bạn có thể phát triển các kỹ năng của bạn trong khuôn khổ của đội?
▪ we need a legal and political framework that is favourable to business.
chúng ta cần một khung pháp lý và chính trị thuận lợi cho hoạt động kinh doanh.
framework for
khuôn khổ cho
▪ the aim of this legislation is to provide a framework for employers and trade unions to operate in.
mục tiêu của luật này là cung cấp một khuôn khổ cho người sử dụng lao động và các công đoàn để hoạt động.

children.name: structure b2
children.definition: structure/ˈstrʌktʃəʳ/  a system, especially a complicated one with a lot of different levels:
examples: cấu trúc, kết cấu
▪ many visitors to the uk find the british class structure difficult to understand.
nhiều du khách đến mỹ thấy lớp học anh có cấu trúc khá khó hiểu.
structure of
cấu trúc của
▪ she studied the organizational structure of the company to see whether it could be made more efficient.
cô nghiên cứu cơ cấu tổ chức của công ty để xem nó có thể được thực hiện hiệu quả hơn hay không.
▪ the structure of the us banking system is changing.
cấu trúc của hệ thống ngân hàng hoa kỳ đang thay đổi.
structurenounarrangement
[ c or u ] the way in which the parts of a system or object are arranged or organized, or a system arranged in this way
_the grammatical structure of a sentence
_the structureofthis protein is particularly complex.
_they have a very old-fashioned management structure.
_some people like the sense of structure that a military lifestyle imposes.
structuralc2adjectivearrangement
relating to the way in which parts of a system or object are arranged
_the political reforms have led to major structural changes in the economy.
structurallyadverb
_few buildings were left structurally safe after the earthquake.

children.name: mechanism c1
children.definition: mechanism a system of rules that makes it possible for particular things to happen or for people to do something: cơ chế
examples: ▪ many schools have a mechanism which allows parents to inspect classroom materials.
mechanism to do something
▪ the peace plan includes a mechanism to share power between all four parties.
mechanism for (doing) something
▪ the free market system is an imperfect mechanism for achieving full employment.

children.name: the way that things or people are arranged
arrangement b2
children.definition: arrangement/əˈreɪndʒmənt/  a group of things that are arranged according to a pattern in order to look attractive:
examples: arrangement of
▪ our chef was never happy until the arrangement of vegetables on each plate was just right.
flower arrangementflowers that have been cut and arranged attractively
▪ a small flower arrangement on the kitchen table can brighten up the room.

children.name: layout c1
children.definition: quy hoạch, bố cục
examples: layout/ˈleɪaʊt/ [countable noun] the way that a building, town, garden, book etc is arranged according to a plan, so that it looks attractive:
▪ a computer program to help you design page layout
chương trình máy tính này giúp bạn thiết kế lại bố cục trang
▪ many of the golfers complained about the course layout.
nhiều gôn thủ than phiền về bố cục khóa học
layout of
▪ he was one of the architects who planned the layout of the hospital.
anh ấy là một trong những kiến trúc sư lên kế hoạch quy hoạch bệnh viện

children.name: order b1
children.definition: order/ˈɔʳdəʳ/  the way that events happen or that information is arranged, showing which is first, which is second, and so on: thứ tự
examples: in this/that/what/any order
▪ it doesn’t matter which order you answer the questions in.
▪ put it into a large mixing bowl and add, in this order, the milk, the honey, the melted butter, and the salt.
order of
▪ we were given a programme showing the order of events for the day.
in order of importance/difficulty/size etcwhen the most important thing is first, then the next most important etc
▪ their main exports, in order of importance, are copper, coal, and maize.
▪ the subjects that students enjoyed most were, in order of popularity, music, history, and art.
in alphabetical orderwith 'a' first, then 'b', then 'c' etc
▪ this index lists each one of the 5 million books in the library, in alphabetical order by title.

children.name: formation c2
children.definition: đội hình
examples: formation/fɔːʳˈmeɪʃən/ [countable/uncountable noun] the way in which a group of planes, ships, soldiers etc are arranged:
▪ formations of tanks were lined up along the border.
đội hình xe tăng được xếp hàng dọc theo biên giới
in formationin a particular pattern or order when flying, marching, or sailing together
theo đội hình
▪ three small planes flying in formation collided this afternoon, killing four people.
ba chiếc máy bay nhỏ đang bay theo đội hình đã va phải nhau chiều nay, giết chết 4 người

children.name: to arrange a group of things or people
arrange b2
children.definition: arrange/əˈreɪndʒ/  to put a group of things or people in a particular order or position: sắp xếp, xếp đặt
examples: arrange sb/sth
▪ why don’t you arrange the kids and i’ll take their picture.
▪ coyle arranged the cushions and sat down on the sofa.
arrange sth in pairs/rows/groups etc
▪ the desks were arranged in pairs.
arrange sb/sth in a circle
▪ can you arrange yourselves in a circle so that everyone can see me?
arrange sth alphabeticallyaccording to the letters of the alphabet
▪ the books are arranged alphabetically, according to author.
arrange sth in order of height/importance etc
▪ if you have a lot of things to do, just make a list and arrange them in order of importance.

children.name: organize b2
children.definition: organize/organiseuk to arrange in order information, ideas etc according to a system, so that they will be more effective or easier to use: thiết lập, sắp đặt
examples: ▪ organize your notes very carefully before giving a speech.
▪ you might find that writing an outline will help you to organize your thoughts.
organize sth into piles/groups etc
▪ the book is organized into three sections.

children.name: set out x
children.definition: set out to arrange a group of things on the floor, on a table, on a shelf etc for people to use, take, or look at: sắp xếp, bày biện
examples: if we set out the chairs now, they’ll be ready for tonight’s meeting.
a waiter brought drinks and sandwiches, and set them out on a low table beside the pool.

children.name: be laid out c1
children.definition: be laid out if atown,buildingetc is laid out in a particular way, it is arranged in that way according to a particular plan: được xếp, được bố trí
examples: i like the way your new office is laid out.
be laid out according to
kyoto is laid out according to a grid system.

children.name: line up c1
children.definition: line up to arrange people or thingsin a line: dàn hàng, xếp thành hàng
examples: ‘line up your men,’ said the police inspector
he lined the dolls up from tallest to shortest.

children.name: put sth in order b1
children.definition: put sth in order to arrange things so that they are in the correct order: xếp thứ tự
examples: he cleaned his desk and put his papers in order before locking up the office.
put sth in alphabetical/numerical order
we need to put all the names in alphabetical order.

children.name: rearrange b2
children.definition: rearrange to arrange a group of things in adifferentwayfrom before:sắp xếp lại
examples: ‘this room looks different. have you painted it?’ ‘no, i just rearranged the furniture.’
this program allows you to create and rearrange images on-screen with the click of a mouse button.

children.name: order x
children.definition: order/ˈɔːʳdəʳ/  to arrange a group of things so that one comes after the other in a particular order: sắp đặt
examples: ▪ the psychology books are ordered according to title, not according to author.

children.name: to put things or people into groups
categorize x
children.definition: categorizealsocategorisebritish /ˈkætɪgəraɪz, ˈkætəgəraɪz/  to decide which group something should belong to, when there is a clear system of separate groups:
examples: chia ,, phân loại
▪ communication involves a variety of behaviours which are difficult to categorise.
categorize something according to something phân loại cái gì dựa vào cái gì
▪ the hotels are categorized according to the standard of the rooms and services they offer.
categorize into phân loại thành
▪ words can be categorised into verbs, nouns, adjectives etc.
▪ animals are categorised into three types - carnivores, herbivores and omnivores.
categorize something as somethingsay which group it is in phân loại cái gì như là cái gì
▪ the store categorizes records from asia and africa as ‘world music’.

children.name: sort b2
children.definition: sort/sɔːʳt/  to arrange a large number of things by putting them into groups, so that you can deal with each group separately:
examples: phân loại , chia
▪ it takes a couple of hours to sort the mail in the morning.
sort something into something chia cái gì thành cái gì
▪ we sorted all the clothes into two piles - those to be kept, and those to be given away.
▪ the rubbish has to be sorted into things that can be recycled and things that can’t
sort something according to something chia cái gì dựa vào cái gì
▪ the eggs are sorted according to size.

children.name: be grouped c1
children.definition: be grouped/biː ˈgruːpt/  if people or things are grouped, they have been put into separate groups according to a system:
examples: được phân nhóm, phân loại
be grouped according to được phân nhóm dựa trên
▪ the vehicles are grouped according to engine size.be grouped together
▪ non-fiction books are grouped together under different subjects.
be grouped into được phân nhóm thành
▪ most european languages can be grouped into two main families.
group something into types/categories/classes etc phân nhóm cái gì thành dạng, danh mục, thứ hạng
▪ the respondents were grouped into three categories - non-smokers, smokers, and ex-smokers.

children.name: classify c1
children.definition: classify/ˈklæsɪfaɪ, ˈklæsəfaɪ/  to decide what group books, plants, animals etc belong to according to an official or scientific system: phân hạng
examples: ▪ scientists have discovered a new type of butterfly which has not yet been classified.classify something as
▪ 43 countries are categorized as ‘low-income’ by the world bank.
▪ babies walking later than 18 months were classified as slow walkers.
classification/ˌklæsɪfəˈkeɪʃən, ˌklæsəfəˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] sự phân loại
▪ there is no common european standard for the classification of hotels.

children.name: class c1
children.definition: class/klɑːsǁklæs/  to say that people or things belong to a particular group, especially according to an official system: phân hạng
examples: class somebody/something as something
▪ this prison houses the most dangerous criminals in britain, those classed as "category a'.
▪ heroin and cocaine are classed as hard drugs.

children.name: grade c1
children.definition: grade/greɪd/  to separate things such as food, drinks, or products into groups according to their quality: phân loại (đồ ăn, thức uống, sản phẩm)
examples: ▪ all the fruit is taken to the warehouse where it is graded and packed.
▪ one supermarket now grades its wines on a scale of 1 to 9, from driest to sweetest.

children.name: to put sb/sth to a particular type
categorize x
children.definition: categorizealso categorise british /ˈkætɪgəraɪz, ˈkætəgəraɪz/  to decide that someone or something belongs to a particular group of people or things that have similar qualities:
examples: categorize somebody/something as something
▪ dali was categorized as a surrealist painter.
▪ forecasts suggest that by the year 2010, only about 30 percent of u.s. households will be categorized as middle class.

children.name: classify c1
children.definition: classify/ˈklæsɪfaɪ, ˈklæsəfaɪ/  to put things or people into particular groups, especially according to an official or scientific system:
examples: classify somebody/something as something
▪ carpentry and furniture making are usually classified as skilled trades.
classify somebody/something by/according to something
▪ wines can be classified according to their sugar content - that is dry, medium or sweet.
▪ eggs are classified by weight as extra large, large, medium, small, and peewee.

children.name: stereotype x
children.definition: stereotype/ˈsteriətaɪp/  to decide unfairly, that certain people have particular qualities, abilities, or needs, for example because they are of a particular sex, race, or social class:
examples: ▪ teachers often stereotype kids who speak with strong regional accents.
stereotype somebody as something
▪ there is a tendency to stereotype childless women as being hard and career-orientated.

children.name: pigeonhole x
children.definition: pigeonhole to say that someone or something can be described as a particular type or group, in a way that is too simple and therefore unfair:
examples: ▪ you shouldn’t pigeonhole people according to your first impressions of them.
▪ when your band becomes successful, people immediately try to pigeonhole you, but we’re into all kinds of music - dance, rock, jazz, blues.

children.name: under
children.definition: /ˈʌndəʳ/  if you include something under a particular category or heading, you decide that it belongs to that particular group of things:
examples: classify/categorize/file/list something under something
▪ in our library, novels are classified under crime, romance, and general.
▪ the association of british travel agents is listed under ‘trade associations and professional bodies’ in the yellow pages.
